p: Stochastic simulations are performed to investigate the uncertainty of climate change impacts on malaria transmission. Fig 9 shows the comparison of malaria incidence (exposed and infected) between simulations under present [CO 2] conditions (S0) and future climate change projections (S1, S2, and S3). Under the elevated [CO 2] condition (S1), we find that the increase of soil moisture due to the changes in water-use efficiency of vegetation resulting in lowered evapotranspiration led to a higher habitat index for Anopheles vectors. As a result, we generally observe an increasing trend of both exposed and infected cases under S1 scenarios (Δ E ≈ 5%, Δ I ≈ 4.5%).
